newsitem.title: UK: Sears shares drop on Freemans sale problems.
newsitem.headline: Sears shares drop on Freemans sale problems.

text.p: Shares in Sears Plc dropped on Wednesday after home shopping firm N. Brown Group Plc said it was withdrawing from negotiations to buy Sears' home shopping business Freemans, dealers said.
The shares fell 3-1/2p to 72-1/2 by 0818 GMT. N. Brown shares jumped 25p to 402-1/2.

"Sears seems to be handling the sale rather badly and they have enough problems without causing these extra difficulties," one market-maker said. 395 million pounds, but the acquisition was referred to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission on competition grounds. Littlewoods then withdrew from the deal when it emerged that Sears was talking to other possible buyers.
N. Brown emerged as the favourite to buy the company, but then announced that "after due diligence, N. Brown felt unable to proceed."
"It's very worrying," one dealer said. "People don't know what's behind N. Brown pulling out. There could be other problems lurking behind it."
Dealers said the news was a further blow to Sears chief executive Liam Strong, who has been under attack from shareholders dissatisfied with his track record on reviving the business.
